Text Area 1: Bullying Prevention Plan  Schools have to have a plan for preventing, identifying, and responding to bullying.  The school has to have the plan in place whether or not any students have been bullied.  Do you want to go through some questions about the requirements for the school-wide plan?

The school doesn't have to include information about their internal policies and procedures that only involve staff.    Did the school send you information about the plan?

Text Area 1: Students with disabilities are entitled to an education that works for them.  This guide covers the requirements for the special education process, starting from the first request for an evaluation.  We will go over the process for identifying whether a student has a disability, to making a plan for the student to access the services they need, to keeping the plan updated year to year.    The guide only asks questions to identify whether the school followed the right process.   Pop up: what does this mean?   Sometimes, a school follows the right process, but the special education services and the plan they offer doesn't work for the student. If you go through the guide and the questions don't address your concerns, call the EdLaw Project intake line at _____.   pop up under "the right process": "What does this mean?" inside the pop up: "The questions will identify issues where the school clearly did or didn't do something (for example, the school didn't follow the right timeline for an evaluation, or the school isn't providing the services in the student's IEP).  The questions don't cover disagreements over what the student needs (for example, whether the student is eligible for special education services, or whether the student needs to be in a smaller classroom), because those situations require more specific details about the student."

Text Area 1:
The first step in the special education process is to ask for an evaluation. Any adult who knows the student can ask for an evaluation. It is best to ask for an evaluation in writing so that there is a record. Make sure to include the date on your request. The rest of this guide explains steps starting after asking for an evaluation for the student.
If you have questions about how to ask for an evaluation, call the EdLaw Project.

Text Area 1: Appeal If the school decided to expel the student, the student has the right to appeal their decision to the School District's superintendent.    Pop up: What is an "appeal"? Inside the pop up: An "appeal" means that the student has the right to have the superintendent review the principal's decision.  If the student requests an appeal, they'll have another hearing with the superintendent where the superintendent decides whether or not they agree with the principal's decision.  The superintendent can change or reverse the principal's decision if they don't agree with it.    Was the student expelled?   pop-up: what does that mean?  inside the pop-up: "Expelled" means excluded from school for over 90 days. An expulsion can also mean that the student is excluded from school indefinitely, or permanently.
